text:
Life continues on, beautiful and kind, fate singing of serenity and calmness.

A fate that cannot last, not when a teacher like Shouta Aizawa chose a student like Izuku Midoriya to be his son in all but blood. 

Still, the students of 1-A appreciate this reprieve, however minor it may be, the day beginning with a peace that can only be known when Izuku Midoriya walks into class long before the bell rings, an entire ten minutes before, happily talking to his peers without any oddities, any changes that would imply a personality swapping assignment. 

And perhaps this is because of the last few weeks, the chaos that Midoriya has brought with the advice of his mentors, two of them encouraging, reveling in the mischief that Midoriya can cause, the last a silent supporter, even when the swaps leave him quaking. To be a boy trained personally by what 1-A can only consider to be the greatest Underground Hero they’ve ever known, Aizawa, the mastermind that is Nedzu himself, and the once Number One Hero in Japan, the man who will forever be the Symbol of Peace, All Might...it is no wonder that ‘normal’ is not a word that can encompass the routine of a boy such as Midoriya.

Yet despite this knowledge, this inescapable truth of life, Midoriya sits around just like the rest of them, content as he talks with some of his friends. Shouto Todoroki sits closest of them all, having moved his chair to be beside his friend. Hitoshi Shinsou leans up against his own desk, with Ochako Uraraka perched on top of his desk. Tsuyu Asui and Tenya Iida stand nearby, the two on either side of Todoroki’s chair, neither phased by how Todoroki only has eyes for Midoriya.

It’s how it’s been for months, after all. 

And this is another fact that is unavoidable, Todoroki’s endless pining for the green haired boy who blesses their life with kindness and chaos. And while this may not mean that the boy has found the courage to ask out Midoriya- Todoroki does have some self-preservation, after all, Aizawa’s wrath a powerful deterrent, although the rest of the class is beginning to see it fade away rather quickly, the dual-haired boy far too enamored with the greenet to simply stay a friend forever, to simply stay away without at least asking for the boy’s hand and risking Aizawa’s fury- well, it certainly does not stop the boy from wanting to hear about Midoriya for hours on end...or perhaps simply hear Midoriya speak for hours.

Nonetheless, it means that a conversation that was once about simple school assignments and plans for the night, all simple ones, with it only being Wednesday, shifts quickly into something else entirely, with Todoroki bringing up Midoriya as the topic to focus on.

“Do you think that Aizawa will give you a new assignment tomorrow or Friday?” Todoroki asks, speaking the very moment that Uraraka ends her excited tangent over her plans to make mochi with Satou, lessons that the chef had promised to finally provide. Midoriya blinks at the sudden change, attention shifting from the now amused Uraraka to the patiently waiting Todoroki. He is the only one caught off guard, the rest unsurprised by this shift, only letting it be, knowing that Todoroki’s pining is far too strong to merely push to the side.

And so Midoriya’s acting once again takes the stage, despite the boy not even acting for the day, the actor shrugging his shoulders before speaking.

“Oh, well...I’m not sure, actually. Aizawa might be giving me a break for the week. He does like to tone it down some, when I have bigger projects recently completed.”

“Like how you acted as Fat Gum last week, kero ,” Asui notes, and Midoriya nods.

“Exactly.” Hand running through his hair, Midoriya admits, “That one was harder than I expected. I was sore for days from Mimic.”

“I think Kirishima cried when you complimented him,” Uraraka says, and then pauses. “No, yeah, he definitely cried.”

“I didn’t mean to do that,” Midoriya says. “It just felt like the proper way to react. Kirishima did really well that day!”

“And shed more tears than you,” Shinsou agrees, and Midoriya flushes red.

“Your raid with Aizawa is another reason that you are likely being given a break, is it not?” Iida asks, kind enough to push the conversation forwards, and Midoriya nods, eager to have something other than his own tears to talk about.

“You mean the one where they took down the entire League of Villains?” Shinsou asks, the rhetorical question dry yet amused. “The very group that has been plaguing you guys since the first week?”

“Maybe Monoma was right,” Uraraka muses. “Maybe you are too powerful, Deku.”

“I’m not, I-” Midoriya turns bright red, face hitting the table as he tries to hide it. “I only fought a few members. I wasn’t that special.”

“Just special enough that you were the only first year to go on the raid,” Asui agrees, a hint of teasing in her voice, and Midoriya makes a noise of protest.

“Mimic gave them the information they needed, I-”

“Didn’t you also use Rewind on Kurogiri?” Todoroki asks, and Midoriya whips his head up.

“Where did you hear about that?”

“Jirou overheard Aizawa bragging about you and Eri,” Shinsou says. 

“A rather parental move, if you ask me.”

Midoriya sputters. “I- he-”

“There, there,” Uraraka says, patting Midoriya on the back. “It’s okay. You’ll see it one day.”

“Aizawa doesn’t think of me as his kid ,” Midoriya says, a statement that no one in the class of 1-A could ever believe except for Midoriya, the boy as oblivious as can be. 

“Sure,” Shinsou says, voice not showing the slightest hints of belief or sincerity, a fact that Midoriya does manage to pick up on.

“You’re not denying that you view him as a dad, though,” Shinsou continues, just as Midoriya opens his mouth, and Midoriya, somehow, manages to make even blushing go Plus Ultra, face turning a shade of scarlet that none of them had ever thought possible.

“We’re going to break him,” Asui notes idly, and Midoriya squeaks in response, perhaps already broken.

“Moving on,” Iida says, once again proving himself to be the saint in Midoriya’s group of friends, “I am curious about that detail of the raid. Midoriya, how were you able to use Rewind so well?”

“Isn’t Eri still having trouble with her Quirk?” Uraraka asks, also intrigued. “If you’re getting into character, wouldn’t that mean you’d be bad with Rewind, too?”

“Eri isn’t bad with her Quirk!” Midoriya defends instantly. “She’s been working on controlling Rewind, just as I’ve been working on Mimic. Aizawa has spent a lot of time helping her, and she’s gotten really far in such a short period of time. It’s incredible, really, and-”

“Okay, big brother,” Shinsou teases. “So her experience transferred over to you?”

“Kind of,” Midoriya responds. “But I’ve been practicing getting into character a lot, so that I could also help her with her Quirk. Rewind is one of the Quirks I’ve dealt with most, actually.” Midoriya pauses, and then admits, “Erasure is also at the top.”

“That’s so cute!” Uraraka says.

“You must feel safest with those Quirks,” Todoroki says, and Midoriya nods. “That makes sense. They are the Quirks of your little sister and father, after all.”

“Todoroki!” Midoriya yelps, and then his phone dings, instantly cutting off any rebuttal that the boy may have had.

Midoriya blinks slowly, then reaches down, pulling his phone out of his pocket and checking the notification.

“It’s from Nedzu,” Midoriya says, unlocking his phone and opening the message. “Maybe he’s cancelling today’s lesson...oh.”

“What does it say?” Asui asks, and Midoriya reads it out loud.

“Enjoy the chaos, Kan was being far too dismissive and Aizawa decided it was time to make a bet. Huh. I wonder what that could be about.”

And just like that, the bell rings and the door slams open.

And Aizawa walks in, eyes glinting in a way that hints of chaos soon to come.

“Follow me, hell class,” Aizawa says, no other greeting coming from his lips. “We’re about to go embarrass Vlad in front of his students.”

And what else can 1-A do except follow?

And so follow is what they do, a class full of confusion and excitement, unsure of where the day will head from there, but ready to see it through nonetheless.

Oh, the things they will see, in just a few moments time…

-----

Izuku Midoriya isn’t sure what he expected, when Aizawa came into the room so suddenly, but it wasn’t to be led to the gyms, where multiple of the Yuuei teachers would already be standing, all at various levels of excitement- one in particular looking more smug than excited, but a show of eagerness nonetheless.

And it definitely was not for Nedzu to pop up from behind a table, waving in order to catch Izuku’s attention.

“Midoriya!” Nedzu chirped. “And let us see...ah, yes! Todoroki, Shinsou, and Bakugou, if you’ll please!”

Izuku blinks, surprised by the sudden call of his name, but the moment he sees Katsuki move forwards, he doesn’t hesitate to do the same, Shinsou and Todoroki only a few steps behind them.

“Good morning,” Nedzu says. “Please, come and take a seat, why won’t you?” Nedzu gestures to the table, where Izuku quickly notes there are five chairs placed perfectly in a row, coordinated and planned.

“Nedzu?” Izuku asks, rather than listening to his mentor. “What are we doing?”

Nedzu grins, something sharp and animalistic and far too familiar, a need for chaos clamped tightly in those jaws. “Why, I’m glad you asked!” Nedzu says, and then he is turning, positioning himself so that he can address both the group before him, and the mass of that is the rest of 1-A mixed with the entirety of 1-B.

“Today, the teachers before you will be acting as our very own Izuku Midoriya! As Midoriya’s only mentor that is not participating, I will act as one of five judges. Todoroki, Shinsou, and Bakugou, as three of Midoriya’s closest friends, who would know him best either from recent times or those past, you have also been selected as judges. Midoriya, you are the final judge, as you will know which consistencies and inconsistencies to look for, their assignment being yourself! Any questions?”

“Can we get this fucking thing started?” Bakugou asks, and Nedzu claps his paws together.

“Absolutely! Actors, to your places! Judges, with me, if you will be so kind.”

Izuku glances at the now much more intrigued group of students, and then at the teachers who wait for their chance to perform. He takes a deep breath, lets it out.

And takes his spot.

He takes the center seat, the only one with a name marked on it. Nedzu is quick to hop into the one on his right, and Todoroki sits to his left. Shinsou sits beside Todoroki, and Katsuki slides into the final spot, which rests on Nedzu’s other side.

Izuku notices that Katsuki seems oddly...stiff, sitting beside the principal. He wonders why that is.

But it’s not his place to ask, and Nedzu seems to take no offense to this abnormal behavior, if anything looking rather pleased by this show of discomfort, so Izuku chooses to turn a blind eye to the oddity.

Instead, Izuku looks at the teachers, takes them all in. There’s Aizawa, of course, the one who had brought them here. And then there is Vlad King, which makes sense, considering the text that Nedzu had sent him just a few moments ago. Yamada’s presence isn’t all too surprising, given how much Izuku’s assignments have affected the man- and how eager Yamada was to play along during Izuku’s time as the blond himself- and neither is Yagi’s appearance, Nedzu having already pointed out that he was the only one of Izuku’s mentors not acting today. 

And so there are four actors, all waiting, some more patiently than others.

Waiting for their chance to begin.

And who is Izuku, to stop a performance from occurring? It goes against his very nature, does it not?

It does, because if Izuku is one thing he is an actor, his Quirk and Aizawa’s influence having made sure of this fact of life, and so Izuku looks to Nedzu for guidance before looking back to the teachers.

"You can begin," Izuku says, and so they do.

They do not come up all at once. No, instead they go one by one, giving Izuku, his friends, and Nedzu the chance to judge them more thoroughly, to analyze their actions and scrutinize their decisions.

And Hizashi Yamada is the first to take the metaphorical stage.

Izuku watches the man step forwards, shoulders carefully loose of tension, smile especially bright. There is no sign of something more sinister, no hint of hurt hidden underneath the surface. There is only joy, only happiness, showing on Yamada’s face.

“He’s only playing your happiest side,” Todoroki says, just moments after Izuku has realized the very same, before the man in question has even spoken.

And when Yamada speaks, Izuku knows that this assumption is correct.

Because when Yamada speaks, he does so with excitement, nothing hesitant in the way he leans forwards and says, “Good morning, guys! Aizawa hasn’t given me an assignment today, but I think he has one planned soon. I’m pretty sure I know what it is, too- but no hints! That’s cheating!”

Izuku gets the feeling that he now understands how his peers felt, the first time he did an assignment on his own, that second day of his swaps. To see only one person playing a role...and for it to be himself, specifically...yeah, he gets why it threw his classmates for a loop.

And it is all the stranger when it is his teacher doing the acting.

Izuku shakes his head, pushing thoughts of oddities to the side and simply allowing himself to enjoy his English teacher’s attempt, noting vague disparities and listening to the comments that his friends and tea-loving mentor offer.

Because each of them has something to offer, when Yamada does something that sparks their interest. Todoroki had said his piece before Yamada could even truly begin, but the other three are also eager to point out differences, taking their roles to heart.

“You’ve never been a showoff with your English,” Katsuki chides when Yamada begins to sing a song from Hamilton, undoubtedly a reference to Izuku’s impersonation of the blond. “You only let people know when you had a reason to.”

“He’s only showing a piece of you,” Shinsou says, right as Yamada reaches the end of his turn. “Only your joy. Where’s the rest?”

“You mean the anxiety?” Izuku murmurs, and Shinsou snorts.

“Anxiety, protectiveness, need to cause eternal chaos...any of it, yeah.”

“I do quite miss the chaos,” Nedzu agrees somberly. “And while Yamada is trying rather hard to mimic you, he is missing most of your body language. You’re rather…”

“Jittery,” Katsuki offers, and Izuku sputters.

“That is one way to put it,” Nedzu agrees, polite but damning. “Your energy simply likes to leak through your skin, Midoriya.”

“You vibrate,” Todoroki consolidates. “It’s when you’re excited, too, so Yamada missed it either way.”

Izuku sighs, then thanks Yamada when the man drops the act, letting the man walk off to the side. Internally, he decides that Yamada did rather well, if only a little too focused on one aspect of himself.

And then Toshinori Yagi walks up, and Izuku realizes that his mentor isn’t much better about that very same issue.

It’s not for a lack of trying, Izuku is sure, but rather a matter of perception. Because Izuku is Yagi’s successor, has been the Symbol of Peace’s protégé long before his swaps, long before Aizawa or Nedzu ever even thought to have an interest in him. He is the ninth to Yagi’s eighth, another name in a legacy that is made of generations of power.

To Yagi, Izuku is young Midoriya. To Yagi, Izuku is his boy, his successor, the next Symbol in the making, or perhaps just another sharer of a Quirk that binds more than blood ever could- ironic, considering that DNA still had to be passed, for such a power to be inherited. To Yagi, Izuku is something like a successor, something like a son , and undeniably someone that Yagi knows well, who Yagi has every right to believe that he would know better than most. He is, after all, one of the few that knows the secret of One for All, having been the one to pass the knowledge off to Izuku.

Izuku will never deny that there is a bond between himself and his mentor. There has to be, for Yagi to have stuck by his side through everything, to have taken pride in a boy once thought Quirkless, and to stay with him in support when it was revealed that Izuku was much more than that timid Quirkless boy that Yagi had picked and trained, had raised to be someone that could reach for his dreams and take them.

Izuku is something quite different, and his bond with Yagi can make the very same claim, and so it is of no surprise to Izuku that Yagi perceives him in a way that captures his persona...but doesn’t quite grasp it.

Because perception is a beauty and a burden, and one’s perception of another can warp their entire understanding of a person, of their personality.

And Yagi sees him in a light that is not cruel, no, but it is in one tinged with nostalgia and the months that were just the two of them, an Izuku that was but no longer quite is .

And so Izuku has to sit in his seat, and feel both flattered that Yagi- that All Might himself, the hero that Izuku spent hours as a child watching on loop- is willing to take the time to act as him as part of this competition...and force down the urge to mimic Todoroki so that he can burst into flames, because Yagi’s main part of the performance focuses on how quickly Izuku’s emotions can shift. And that’s great, truly! It’s a sign that Yagi can perceive multiple aspects of his character, and can tie them together, which is already better than Yamada’s attempt to merely focus on his cheerful side. 

But it’s mainly just his crying that Yagi ends up emphasizing. Well, that and his fanboy tendencies, which Izuku can fully admit that he has, and was especially bad about when first training with his mentor- and who can blame him, really?- but that doesn’t quite mean that he wants them broadcasted to the entire first year hero department...and by one of his greatest idols, no less.

And yet Yagi is beaming when he drops the act, so sure of himself, so proud, that Izuku can’t bring himself to do anything except offer his mentor a thumbs up and a grin that the blond matches instantly before walking off, the man rather pleased and far too oblivious to Izuku’s quickly reddening face.

A warmth that only gets worse when his friends turn to him, each wearing looks that speak of mischief and delight intertwined.

“Spot on,” Katsuki says, the little shit that he always has been. “I doubt either of the others can top that. Ten out of ten, or whatever.”

“We’re no longer friends,” Izuku mutters, and Katsuki snorts.

“As if,” Katsuki retorts, and, well, Izuku doesn’t have an actual rebuttal for that. 

“He was better than Yamada,” Shinsou offers, but his smile is still a bit too cheeky for Izuku’s liking. “Honestly, he reminds me of how you were before the swaps.”

Izuku nods, pushing his embarrassment aside to respond. “You’re right,” Izuku agrees. “If I had never started doing the assignments, I probably would be more like that still.”

“As if you’ve changed that much,” Katsuki says. “You’ve just picked up a spine that sticks around, you’re still the same brat I grew up with.”

Izuku blinks, then smiles. “Is that a compliment?” He asks, and Katsuki sputters.

“How the fuck was that a compliment?” Katsuki asks, and Shinsou nods.

“That was definitely a compliment.”

Todoroki hums, and Izuku turns to look at his friend. “Bakugou is right. You’re still you, Midoriya. You haven’t become drastically different since the beginning of the year...you’ve just grown into yourself more, I think.”

Izuku smiles at the words, touched. “Thanks, Todoroki! That’s really sweet.”

“Of course,” Todoroki says, and Izuku tries not to overthink the pink tint that shows on his friend’s face. “Although it’s not just me who sees it. Clearly, your original dad sees it as well.”

“Original…” Izuku pouts. “Todoroki! Yagi isn’t my dad!”

“And neither is Aizawa,” Todoroki says, as if implying the opposite, to which Izuku sputters even more.

“Yes!” Izuku says, and is met with not one, not two, but four sighs from the rest of the table, causing him to whip around. “What? What am I missing?”

“Both of your dads, apparently,” Katsuki mutters, but then Nedzu is clapping his paws together.

“Alright! Vlad King, if you’ll please!” Nedzu calls out, and Izuku blinks.

“I’m surprised Vlad King isn’t going last,” Izuku admits. “I would have thought that Aizawa wanted to show his own act before, to embarrass Vlad.”

“It’ll be more embarrassing after,” Shinsou says. “Especially if Vlad sucks.”

And Shinsou is right...because while Izuku thought Yagi was decent, and Yamada was okay...Vlad doesn’t even deserve last.

Is it petty to wish to give someone a lower ranking than there were competitors? Izuku isn’t sure, but watching the 1-B homeroom teacher take his entire personality and do the metaphorical equivalent of throwing it in sewage, Izuku is willing to forgo niceties for this case.

Vlad King, Izuku quickly realizes, has no idea what Izuku is like, or what he represents. It’s understandable, Izuku supposes, considering that the man teaches 1-B, and not 1-A, and therefore would have much more limited knowledge on him compared to his teachers. 

But Vlad King should still have some knowledge, especially thanks to the more recent months that have passed. Months of acting assignments, of Izuku going around the school, from 1-A to 1-B to support, from being heroes from Yuuei to those of other schools, or just ones without any teaching jobs at all...Izuku has even been villains ! Izuku has put himself in Vlad King’s vicinity so many times by now, has given the man many chances to see him and analyze his character, if only Vlad took the time to look back and remember. 

And yet it’s clear, from the moment that Vlad King opens his mouth, that the man has dismissed the past entirely, creating a character for Izuku based only on his beliefs and the acts that Yamada and Yagi have put on.

Quite honestly, Izuku cannot tell what the worst part is. But if he had to narrow it down, it would either be the very beginning, where Vlad King took Izuku’s acting as an implication that Izuku is an overly confident boy with no anxiety whatsoever- a world Izuku could never dream of existing in, his stress too perpetual and undoubtedly trying to give him white hairs before his second year even begins- or the end, where Vlad sees the disappointed looks from the blonds that had already gone, and completely changes his act.

Giving Izuku part two of the crybaby Izuku series.

“Oh what the fuck ,” Izuku mutters, and Shinsou stifles a laugh under his breath, disguising it with a cough. 

Traitor.

Even Monoma seems disappointed in his teacher by the time that the man finally stops, and Izuku is pretty sure that that says quite a lot about the performance. Izuku watches as Vlad King walks away, smug and self-assured, and then turns to his friends and mentors.

“Is that how you guys see me?” Izuku asks, and his friends shake their heads immediately.

“He’s just shit at acting,” Katsuki confirms, and Izuku lets out a sigh of relief when even Nedzu agrees with the sentiment.

“Thank kami...okay, let’s finish this.”

And then Izuku can pretend that his entire state of being wasn’t reduced to an act like that .

Aizawa steps up to the center, and Izuku watches eagerly, waiting to see what his final mentor will do.

He’s not disappointed.

No, Izuku is not disappointed in the slightest. Rather, Izuku finds himself leaning forwards, delighted as he watches Aizawa rub at his eyes before slipping into character, posture shifting from slouched shoulders and a subtle lean into something both more excitable and more nervous, back straightening and hands slipping out of pockets to show that they are half-clenched, as if unsure whether to ball up or flatten out. Aizawa smiles, and it doesn’t look quite right on his face, but he lifts one of his hands to run through his hair, brushing the strands back, and oh, that’s a move Izuku does quite often, isn’t it?

But Aizawa goes further than physical movements, words precise and perfectly picked, sounding quite like Izuku as he questions why Nedzu has called for him, if there’s another assignment, even going into a miniature muttering spree as he tries to guess who his next assignment will be.

“Your dads are so spot on,” Shinsou says, and Izuku can’t even tear his focus away long enough to get flustered by the title once again.

And Izuku could go on, could ramble endlessly about how fascinating it is, seeing his homeroom teacher pick out his little tells and apply them seamlessly. He could theorize on if the feeling is similar to how his teachers have felt, seeing him do the exact same thing. The precision of it all is surprising and inspiring, and Izuku has to ignore the urge to join his teacher and start acting as well, the call to put on a show annoyingly great.

Izuku could go on, yes, but for once...for once, it feels best to leave the words unspoken, to let the actions simply be enjoyed and appreciated.

And so Izuku keeps his mouth shut, only speaking once Aizawa is finished.

“He wins,” Izuku says, and not a soul disagrees.

And so Aizawa takes first in the miniature competition, Yagi claiming second and Yamada content with third.

And Vlad King stuck with the knowledge that acting is quite a bit harder than it seems. 

And all is well with the world, just as it should be.

And Izuku is content. Flustered, embarrassed, and appreciated, and content despite, or perhaps because, of it all.

(The day continues, something quite calm until the end.)

Shouta Aizawa is content at the end of the day, when the bell rings and his students are eager to race out of the room, ready to head back to the dorms so that they can relax before getting their homework done. Shouta is happy enough to stand up and do the same, gathering his papers easily enough, ready to head back to his on-campus apartment. It’s a building shared by all of the teachers, a place that Eri is happy to reside in, which is more than enough for Shouta’s approval. It gives her a chance to acclimate to the company of others, and allows Shouta to have his colleagues watch over her when he cannot, without putting any of them out of their way.

It’s their main place of residence, although Shouta often has them stay in the 1-A dorms, too, an apartment of their own located within the walls of Heights Alliance. His class finds chaos easily enough on their own, after all, without Shouta's influence coming into play. Whether it be clumsy mistakes made by teenagers who have never lived in dorms before this year, or villains attacking, or secrets with lifespans of over two hundred years being admitted by his resident Problem Child, Shouta is often around to make sure that he can help his students through whatever dilemma comes up.

And he never regrets it, even if it means missing sleep, even if it means going back and forth between his different apartments.

Not when it means that he is there for his class.

But today, Shouta is not staying in the 1-A dorms. He has patrol tonight, which means that he will stay in the teachers’ apartments, so that Eri is near other adults should she need anything in the night, when Shouta is gone and his students should be asleep. She’s been sleeping easier, ever since the most recent raid, her confidence having spiked with the successful use of Rewind on Shouta’s high school friend.

Shouta smiles at the reminder of this good news, at Oboro’s return. The boy is back, if still the age that he had been when gone. Their friendship will never be the same, no, too much time has passed...but he is glad that his once close friend has a chance to continue the life Shouta knew he would want. 

Shouta got the chance to visit him, just the other day. He was reunited with his parents as soon as he was awake and considered stable, no side effects from everything that had happened to him, fortunately. 

“There’s so much to do!” Oboro had said, and yet he had looked thrilled by the admittance. “Shouta, it’s so strange! Everything has changed so much, and I’m the only one catching up to what everyone else views as normal. I feel like a kid in some manga, having been sent to the future. Is this what time travel feels like? It’s kind of cool, let me tell you.”

Shouta will take Oboro’s word for it, and he let the boy know exactly that. 

He thinks Eri will like to meet him. Maybe in the next few weeks, when they have the time.

Maybe Midoriya would like to go, too. Midoriya was one of the key forces behind the entire raid, after all, the reason they knew to do everything in the first place.

And maybe Shouta just wants to let Oboro meet both of his kids, to prove Oboro wrong. They had joked, when they were younger, that Shouta would only ever have cats for children.

And now Shouta has two that he calls his own, one of which he has adopted, one of which he happily would.

One who is approaching him, forcing Shouta out of his thoughts with a hesitantly asked, “Aizawa?”

“Yes, Problem Child?” Shouta asks, and Midoriya gives him an odd look.

“You’ve been staring at that paper for quite a while.”

“Ah.” A glance at the clock lets him know that a few minutes have already passed, a look around the room shows that Midoriya is the only one left in the room. “I was thinking of something, thank you.” 

Midoriya nods, looking pleased, and only starts to leave the room when Shouta does the same. He seems content enough, just walking beside Shouta, and Shouta hides his smile at this fact, at the way that his kid is at ease with his company.

And yet Shouta is confused, because, “Problem Child, it’s Wednesday.”

“Yep!” Midoriya agrees easily enough, causing Shouta to blink slowly, lost.

“Don’t you have lessons with Nedzu today?”

“Oh, not today,” Midoriya says. “He said that my analysis of you all this morning was enough work, and told me to enjoy a break.”

“That’s good,” Shouta says. “You should do that.”

“I will,” Midoriya agrees. “Todoroki actually asked me if I want to leave campus for a bit, maybe grab something to eat. I was wondering if I could bring Eri with us- I know she loves this one cafe nearby, and Todoroki said she was welcome to join if you approved.”

Shouta hums. If Eri comes, it’s not a date, even if the idea sounds far too much like one otherwise. 

But Midoriya seems far too excited by the idea, and it would be good for Eri to go with them so that she can get out more…

‘ Todoroki knows exactly what he’s doing, ’ Shouta realizes with a scowl, and yet he can’t help but be impressed. At least his student is smart about it, if not clever enough that Shouta won’t catch on.

“You can go,” Shouta agrees. “Just make sure to be back by eight, so that Eri isn’t up too long.”

“Of course! The teachers’ apartments tonight, sensei?”

“Yes.” Shouta smiles, then adds, “Thank you. Eri enjoys spending time with you.”

“I enjoy spending time with her, too!” Midoriya responds immediately. “She’s like a little sister to me.”

And Midoriya is constantly referred to as her older brother, a habit that has only increased since it’s first appearance in December. Shouta wonders if Midoriya knows that this habit has not stopped, but doubts that the boy would mind.

Instead he lets the topic drop, letting Midoriya steer its course instead. And Midoriya picks up the slack soon enough, asking, “Why did you guys do the acting assignment, anyways? I understand that Vlad King was being somewhat dismissive of my acting, but for so many of you to act as me...was there a reason?”

“Sometimes, the best way to prove a point is to show the opposition how wrong they were,” Shouta says easily. “In this case, it was showing Vlad that he was being foolish and ignorant.”

“Well, you were really good at acting! Is it because you’re an Underground Hero?” Midoriya asks. “That makes sense...you’ve probably had to infiltrate groups, which would require a persona of your own...you never mentioned that you could act!”

“It’s nothing as exciting as your acts,” Shouta brushes off. “I’ve done a few infiltrations, but nothing as elaborate as your swaps.”

‘ Besides, ’ Shouta thinks. ‘ It’s rather easy to imitate the kid I view as my own. If I had to be Bakugou...no. ’

Shouta blinks when he notices that Midoriya has gone silent, and then realizes that the boy has stopped following. He turns around, sees Midoriya staring right back, face turning red.

“You think of me as your own?”

Shouta blinks again, but Midoriya fills in the silence.

“You said that out loud. You didn’t mean to, did you? Wait, does that mean Shinsou and Todoroki weren’t joking? But- but why me?” He doesn’t seem upset by the realization, just confused, which is a reaction that Shouta hadn’t expected, either.

“Why not?” Shouta asks.

“Because it’s me,” Midoriya says. “You know what I’m like.”

“Exactly,” Shouta agrees. “You’re my Problem Child, who was Quirkless for most of his life yet pushed through the shit life threw at you because of it. You’re my student who has managed to gain control over two Quirks, one over a decade late to reveal itself, and one that has the power of centuries behind it. You’re the kid who managed to turn out as the personification of heroism, despite all that you’ve had to go through. Why wouldn’t I want to consider you my kid?”

“Really?” Midoriya asks, voice shaky and unsure but eyes shining with tears and something that looks quite like hope. “You- you think all of that?”

“Really,” Shouta assures. “You are my kid, and have been for quite some time.”

“Even though I’m not actually your kid, like Eri is?” Midoriya asks, and Shouta nods.

And Midoriya bursts into tears, surging into Shouta’s arms, barely giving the man time to brace himself before his kid is crying into his chest. Shouta doesn’t hesitate to wrap his arms around the boy, offering him the comfort that his kid needs.

“I always wanted a dad,” Midoriya murmurs, and Shouta’s heart both breaks for his son and fills because of him.

(And the conversation continues from there, a father and his son held together by bonds not made by blood nor paper but by choice, by a fate that was created from threads that have been stitched together, a fate that was realigned for the sake of both parties in question.

The conversation continues, and so does life, beautiful and hopeful in all of its glory.

And fate carries on, singing sweetly of good to come.

A song of family and love, and all that comes with it.)
